options: Raise your concerns with your clinical supervisor
Ignore the situation
Perform a diary card exercise to record the number of hours you are working and your breaks
Confront Melissa and tell her that you will inform her clinical supervisor unless she clerks your patients for the rest of the afternoon
Inform the nurse in charge of Melissa's behaviour
Speak to the other F2's about Melissa and tell them you think that she's not pulling her weight
Refuse to work with Melissa
Approach Melissa separately and discuss your observations with her
questions:
You are a F2 working in a busy Emergency Department. You are constantly rushed off your feet and find it difficult to take a lunch break. You also find that you stay an hour or more past the end of your shift nearly every day. You notice your F2 colleague, Melissa, often has a lot of time to spare and does not appear as busy as you or the rest of the F2's in the department. A number of times you have seen her sitting in the doctor mess when there's a queue of patients waiting to be seen.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The correct options are 1, 3 and 8. This is a difficult situation but the first step to addressing a colleague who is not pulling their weight is to discuss your observations directly with them (option 8). They may be struggling at work and need extra support. The second step is to raise your concerns with your clinical supervisor who should be your point of call for all day-to-day issues (option 1). This may be something your supervisor is already aware of and are dealing with. The third step is to look at why you and your fellow F2's are struggling to take a break and feel rushed off your feet. Is the department under pressure? Is there enough staff to cover the demand in the Emergency Department? Are you working longer hours than your rota? These are all issues that need to be raised with the department. Diary carding is an important part of monitoring the hours that you are working to ensure that your rota is complaint and you are getting adequate breaks. Hence, option 3 would be the last best option.

Refusing to work with Melissa is likely to cause friction in the team and is unnecessary (option 7). Ignoring the situation will solve nothing (option 2). Confronting and bribing a colleague is never a good idea and will again cause friction (option 4). Informing the nurse in charge is not necessary in this scenario as you should go to your clinical supervisor in this situation (option 5). Speaking to the other F2's about Melissa's behaviour fuels gossip and does not achieve a purpose (option 6).

options: Find the nurse who gave you the equipment and inform her that she did not check the expiry date
Ignore the situation, the cannula has already been flushed
Apologise to the patient and inform them of the mistake
Inform the ward manager
Complete a clinical incident form
Send an e-mail to your colleagues suggesting they double check the saline expiry dates before administration
Check the patient for any adverse signs
In your break have a look through the stock cupboards to check that other medications and fluids are within expiry date
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in the Respiratory Unit. You insert a cannula in a patient for IV antibiotics and you flush it with 10mls of 0.9% saline given to you by a nurse. Whilst you are disposing of the equipment, you realise that the saline is out of date and expired 6 months ago.

Choose the THREE most appropriate important initial actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The correct options are C, D and G. This question relates to the professional duty of candour. Every healthcare professional must be open and honest with patients when something that goes wrong with their treatment or care causes, or has the potential to cause, harm or distress. Therefore, it is important that you inform the patient of your mistake and apologise to them for the error (option C).

Check for any adverse effects as patient safety is crucial (option G).

As one medication has been found to be out of date, it's important that the ward manager has been informed (option D) to ensure a check is carried out to look for other drugs past their expiry date.

Option E is important but is not as pressing as CDG. It may take several days before the clinical incident form is reviewed and longer before it is acted upon.

Option F is a poor and unreliable method of disseminating information to colleagues.

Option A is passing the blame on to another colleague. Ignoring the situation (option B) is not sensible as you are not taking accountability for your actions and may be putting patient safety at risk. Checking to see whether other medications and fluids are within expiry date in the stock cupboard (option H) is not part of your role as a junior doctor.

See the GMC explanatory guidance on 'Openness and honesty when things go wrong' here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/27234.asp

options: Discuss with your colleague how he is feeling and what is going on
Suggest to your colleague that he speaks to his educational supervisor
Inform the GMC
Voice your displeasure over your colleagues behaviour to other members of staff
Inform your consultant of your concerns over your colleague
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a ward. You find your fellow ST1 doctor asleep in the doctors lounge in the middle of a busy shift. You have noticed that the quality of his work has decreased as of late and you feel that you have been carrying some of his workload for a while.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in the question are those of working as part of a team and supporting other members of staff.

During a busy shift it is not professional for your colleague to be asleep in the doctors lounge, as this is neglectful of his duties. However, there may be a reason why he the quality of his work has decreased recently. As his colleague your first response, and the most appropriate in this scenario, is to approach him as a friend and ask him what is going on. This shows that you genuinely care and want to help. If he informs you that nothing has happened and he continues in this way then it may be necessary to escalate it to a senior in the future. However, the most appropriate first response is to talk to him about how he has been recently (1).

The next most appropriate action would be to suggest to your colleague that he goes and speaks with his educational supervisor (2). Educational supervisors are there to help doctors with any issues that they may have, whether they be issues about the job or something completely unrelated, such as difficulties at home. This is more preferable than informing your consultant of your concerns (5) as you are allowing your colleague time to deal with his issues himself, as opposed to going over his head and escalating immediately.

Voicing your displeasure over your colleagues behaviour to other members of staff (4) is unprofessional. Gossiping behind a colleagues back will not help your colleague in the long run. Furthermore, it may actually do harm as the staff members that you speak to may lose confidence in your colleagues ability, creating a difficult working environment. Working as part of a team is a vital part of being a doctor, and maintaining a team ethos is an important part of that.

The least appropriate option in this scenario is informing the GMC (3). Informing the GMC is a vast over-reaction to the original situation and is a waste of both time and resources.

options: Advise her to see one of the senior GPs for a second opinion
Tell her she should pay for a private referral
Politely refuse explaining it is your decision about management
Remove her from the practice list
Refer her to a paediatrician
questions:
You are a GP registrar. A mother brings her 2-year-old child into surgery. She is concerned about his frequent bouts of coughing and wheezing. Whenever the child has been seen the clinical impression has been viral-induced wheeze. Plotting his growth shows he is consistently on the 50th centile for both height and weight. It transpires that the mother is concerned about asthma. She demands a referral to a paediatrician for further tests. Despite extensive discussions she is still concerned.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is a situation that requires a balanced approach. As a principle doctors are of course free to make decisions regarding management and are not obliged to follow patient requests. However, the mother clearly has concerns about her child. Such concerns should always be acknowledged and taken seriously, not least because parents know their children best and are often right.

If a mother cannot be reassured about her child then the best course of action as a GP registrar is to ask a senior GP at the practice to review the child. If this fails to reassure the mother than a referral to paediatrics is the next best option.

Refusing to refer the child is likely to lead to ongoing anxiety. Telling her to pay for a private referral is a poor option as it gives the impression that the child would benefit from review but that you are not willing to do it on the NHS.

Disagreements with patients about management are not grounds for practice list removal.

options: Refuse to prescribe the pill and take no further action
Telephone the local Child Protection Officer for advice
Agree to prescribe the oral contraceptive pill depending on whether she attends a 'safer sex' course
Inform her mother
Prescribe the combined oral contraceptive pill
questions:
A 15-year-old girl comes into surgery requesting to start the combined oral contraceptive pill. She tells you that her boyfriend is also 15-years-old. Despite you encouraging her she will not tell her mother.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario touches on Fraser competence. Whilst the girl is technically engaging in a sexual relationship that is against the law, you have a duty as her doctor to act in her best interests.

Prescribing the combined oral contraceptive pill will protect the patient from the physical, psychological and social consequences of an unwanted pregnancy.

Contacting the local Child Protection Officer is always an option but as this is such a common scenario it should not be necessary.

Whilst attending a course on 'safer sex' may be beneficial it is not appropriate to bargain with a patient like this. This patient is likely to continue having sex whether you prescribe the pill or not - by refusing to do so she is just more likely to have an unwanted pregnancy.

Informing her mother is the least acceptable option as the situation does not warrant you to break confidentiality.

options: Advise the endoscopy unit that consent is not required as it is for emergency treatment
Consent the patient
Discuss the situation with the senior charge nurse on the ward
Discuss the situation with the registrar when they are available
Inform the consultant immediately
questions:
You are the F2 doctor working in the gastroenterology ward. You are looking after a 72-year-old man with an upper gastrointestinal bleed. He is hemodynamically stable and requires an endoscopy. The endoscopy unit calls the ward and asks you to consent to the patient prior to him being transferred. You have limited knowledge required in consenting to this procedure. The registrar on the ward is currently at a cardiac arrest. The consultant is in the clinic but is accessible via the page.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
The question is focused on consent, working within your competencies, and appropriate escalation to a senior. The GMC has specific guidance which states: 'Consent is a fundamental legal and ethical principle. All patients have the right to be involved in decisions about their treatment and care and to make informed decisions if they can' and 'You must recognise and work within the limits of your competence'.

Informing the consultant immediately is the most appropriate action. The patient requires consent and informing the consultant is the best way to achieve this in a timely manner. They are ultimately responsible for the patient's care and should be informed anyway if there is a potential incident that could affect patient safety.

Discussing the situation with the registrar when they are available is a somewhat appropriate action. However it is not known how long the registrar will be at the cardiac arrest, and thus contacting the consultant is the preferable option.

Discussing the situation with the senior charge nurse on the ward is a less appropriate action. Although they may be able to offer advice, they will not be able to rectify the underlying problem.

Consenting the patient is an inappropriate action. Only suitable trained and competent clinicians should consent.

Advising the endoscopy unit that consent is not required as it is for emergency treatment is entirely inappropriate. All medical and surgical interventions require consent when dealing with patients who have mental capacity regardless of whether or not it is an emergency. This option does not even attempt to obtain consent making it the most inappropriate response. In contrast, the previous option at least demonstrates the motive to obtain the necessary consent.

title: GMC: Consent - Making decisions about investigations and treatment
body:
The GMC provides in-depth guidance on gaining consent from patients for treatment. When referring to treatment, not just invasive or dangerous procedures such as surgery are taken into account but all forms of treatment including changes to medication or how to investigate a condition. The guidance explains how and what information should be shared with patients to gain consent, who can make decisions on their behalf if a patient cannot and how consent is expressed and recorded.

Providing information:
  • You should explain all the available treatment options to the patient and the benefits and risks of each treatment
  • If you think a treatment is more appropriate you should make a recommendation but ensure you do not bias the patient or coerce them into choosing your preference for treatment
  • When discussing the risks of a treatment you should provide information regarding any risks which would be relevant to the patient; this may be both because they are serious but rare or because they are common but less significant
  • You are obliged to ensure the patient is aware of the risks of a procedure unless they have specifically asked not to be informed; do not assume they would not want to know
  • Even when patients request that information is withheld, you must still ensure that they are aware of the risks associated with any treatment so consent can be obtained
  • You can only withhold information when it would cause 'significant harm' to the patient when giving it; there needs to be evidence, not just a doctor's feeling that it would upset or dissuade a patient
  • You should answer any questions honestly and as fully as you can, even if you think this will result in them withdrawing consent for a procedure

Explaining risks:
  • The discussion should be tailored to the individual and risks adjusted based on their co-morbidities and personal background as appropriate
  • You must always explain side-effects and possible complications of a treatment as well as the risk of failure of treatment

Obtaining and recording consent:
  • You must document in the medical records that a patient has consented to a treatment based on the information given to them; you must record the benefits and risks you have explained
  • This must be done both for trivial treatments such as a new oral medication as well as more significant treatments such as surgical procedures
  • Written consent should be obtained for procedures with significant risk or significant impact on the patient's social situation to formally document the conversation regarding benefits and risks. This should be in addition to recording in the medical records that they have given consent
  • You are legally required to gain written consent for fertility treatment
  • Where possible, the patient should be provided with written information regarding the risks and benefits discussed if the treatment is significant; this may include a copy of a consent form or clinic letter or a leaflet with further information
  • In the case of patients under 16, consent must be sought from the parents and their written consent must be documented

Non-competent patients:
  • Any patient who cannot consent for themselves, either due to a reduced conscious level or a cognitive impairment, can still have treatment in their best interests
  • The reasons for carrying out the procedure must be clearly documented

Examples

A 46-year-old woman is going to undertake a prophylactic mastectomy for familial breast cancer
  • Ideally, in this situation you would consent her days to weeks prior to the procedure to ensure she has time to ask questions and consider her decision to undergo the procedure
  • You should gain separate written consent (i.e. complete a consent form) as well as documenting the conversation regarding risks and benefits and her expressing consent in the medical notes
  • The benefits and reasons for the procedure, the risks of the procedure itself, possible post-operative complications and the possibility of failure of treatment should all be discussed and documented

A 91-year-old man attends his GP to have his diabetic medications adjusted
  • While much less significant than a surgical procedure, you should still document the patient's consent to undergo further treatment for their diabetes in the medical notes; this can be as simple as noting they agree to change medications or doses
  • You should provide him with all the options available and allow him to make a choice based on the side effects and benefits of each medication
  • You can recommend a specific drug if you feel it is best and give your reasons for this recommendation but if he wishes to choose another treatment and decline your recommendation then you must not coerce him into following your advice

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a head injury and requires emergency neurosurgery for a life-threatening intracranial bleed
  • There are two important rules to note here which is that as the patient is under 16, responsibility to consent for procedures is deferred to the parents as the law assumes she does not have the capacity to conConsent - Making decisions about investigations and treatmentsent for herself and that as this is an emergency and she is unconscious, a procedure can be done in a patient's best interests without obtaining consent
  • It would be reasonable to either discuss the procedure with her parents and gain consent from them for emergency surgery or to perform the surgery without seeking consent but to discuss the surgical plan with the parents as the relatives as you would if the patient was an adult and able to consent for themselves
  • The risks of the procedure should be explained but the key difference in explaining them here is that without surgery the patient is likely to die and so any post-operative complications are less serious than the risks of continuing without surgery
  • Time pressures mean all questions may need to be answered immediately and it is good practice to document what questions were asked of you by the relatives if any and your answers at the time; often people do not have questions and you should also document this if it is the case
  • The full discussion with the parents should be fully documented in the medical records including the main risks of performing surgery as well as the likely outcome without operative management and that formal consent from the patient themselves cannot be sought with the reasons why documented clearly

A 51-year-old man is having a benign skin lesion removed for cosmetic purposes
  • These cases where the procedure is not being carried out to increase function / prevent disability or preserve life are where consent should be most detailed
  • The benefits should be clearly listed and when discussing risks, usual surgical effects such as pain and scarring should be explained and consented for as these may cause the patient to not give consent for a purely cosmetic procedure
  • The consent process should ideally be over a number of consultations with consent being taken in advance of the procedure and confirmed on the day to ensure the patient has had time to ask any questions and is fully aware of the risks before undergoing the procedure

options: Shout for help
Withhold CPR until you know his resuscitation status
Begin CPR
Assume he has a DNACPR form and note the time of death
Ask a nurse to find out his DNACPR status
Find out his DNACPR status
Bleep his team
Do nothing
questions:
You are a surgical junior doctor. You are on your way to the canteen for lunch one afternoon when you notice that an elderly gentleman has collapsed in the corridor. You rush over to him and notice that he has a hospital wristband on, but he is unfamiliar to you. You check for signs of life and find that he has suffered a cardiac arrest. You are aware that many elderly hospital inpatients have a DNACPR form in place. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
In this situation, where you come across a collapsed patient and have no immediate access to their DNACPR status, the most appropriate action would be to shout for help and begin CPR as normal. If you do the opposite and wait until you have found out whether or not he is a candidate for CPR, and you find out that he should have received CPR, you are likely to have wasted too much time and CPR is then even less likely to be successful. You can always stop giving CPR if it turns out he is not a candidate. The best thing to do is get a nurse or other employee to contact the ward and look up his CPR status while you continue to give it.

As stated above, you should not withhold CPR just because you are unsure. Also assuming he has a form is very dangerous as you may be entirely incorrect. Bleeping the on-call cardiologist is inappropriate in this situation - they are unlikely to be able to help you, and you are wasting valuable time when you should be delivering CPR. If you are off finding out his DNACPR status, then clearly you are not able to deliver CPR. You should only go and find out this information if someone is there performing effective CPR for you.

title: Decisions relating to cardiopulmonary resuscitation
body:
The following paragraph has been taken from the 'Decisions relating to cardiopulmonary resuscitation' guidelines from the Resuscitation Council:


Where a patient has not appointed a welfare attorney or made an advance decision, the treatment decision rests with the most senior clinician responsible for the patients care. Where CPR may re-start the patients heart and breathing for a sustained period, the decision as to whether CPR is appropriate must be made on the basis of the patients best interests (or benefit in Scotland). In order to assess best interests, where possible the views of those close to the patient must be sought, to determine any previously expressed wishes and what level or chance of recovery the patient would be likely to consider of benefit, given the inherent risks and adverse effects of CPR
concept: If you discover a patient has suffered a cardiac arrest and have no immediate access to their resus status, the correct thing to do would be to commence CPR as usual

questions:
You are working as a GP registrar. A patient, Ian, 36, brings his child, Charlie, 4, to see you with a burn on his hand, due to him touching a hot radiator. On examination the burn appears mild, however on general inspection you notice Charlie looks very thin, malnourished and has dirty clothing on. On further questioning, Ian reveals he was asleep following binging on alcohol at home. Ian and Charlie live together alone, as Charlie's mother died last year. Ian reveals that since her death he has struggled at home and has started consuming considerably more alcohol, but he is planning on reducing his consumption.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most appropriate response in this scenario would be to speak to your senior GP about the potential child safety concerns that you have (C). Ian consuming large quantities of alcohol could result in Charlie being neglected, which is what the question is suggesting. That means that child safety needs to be considered. With you having only recently started working in general practice, and being a more junior member of the medical team at the practice, it would be wise to seek advice from a more senior GP.

Following seeking senior advice, contacting social services (A) would be the next most appropriate option. Charlie's safety is potentially in danger in this scenario, with this evidenced by him already having burnt himself whilst unattended. Therefore, social services should be informed, and the safety of the household assessed.

Eliciting more information regarding Ian's alcohol consumption (B) would be a good thing to do. Ian needs to cut down/stop drinking alcohol whilst being solely in charge of Charlie. However, addressing Ian's alcohol drinking habits does not immediately deal with the safety of Charlie in the household. Therefore, it is a good thing to do, but not as immediate as the prior options.

Contacting the police (D) is an unnecessary and incorrect response to this scenario, as what happened was not a criminal act. However, while handing Ian self help leaflets and group information (E) sounds like a good response to the scenario, this is in fact the worst option. This option does not address Charlie's safety at home, as Ian may not take the advice in the leaflets and continue consuming large quantities of alcohol whilst leaving Charlie unattended. Therefore, this is the worst of the options.

options: Tell the medical director the next day
Tell her that you can smell alcohol on her breath and that she shouldn't be in work
Speak to her about it the next day and see if she needs help
Carry on as normal as you have a busy clinic to get through
Excuse yourself from clinic and inform one of her colleagues who is in his office
questions:
You are a ST doctor and turn up to clinic with the consultant. You can smell alcohol strongly on her breath.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
In a difficult situation such as this the best option is to be upfront with the consultant as patients could be put at risk by allowing her to continue with her clinic (2). Speaking to one of her colleagues is also a good option as they could offer to take over the clinic and prevent the risk to patients (5). Speaking to her the next day to see if she needs help is a good option to help the consultant but puts patients at risk by allowing the clinic to continue (3). Informing the medical director the next day again doesn't address the risk to patients in clinic (1). Ignoring the situation is the worst option (4).

By arriving at work intoxicated a doctor is not fit to practice as there is a real risk to patients. This is therefore a GMC issue.

GMC. Duties of a doctor. Professionalism in action.

Persuade the girl to tell her parents
Enquire further about her partner and their relationship
Report the matter to the social services

questions:
You are a junior doctor working in General Practice. A 15-year-old girl comes in unaccompanied. She tells you that her and her boyfriend would like to start having a sexual relationship and asks for advice regarding contraception.

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
A doctor can give contraceptive advice and treatment provided he is satisfied that she fulfils the following criteria:
  • That the girl (under 16) will understand the advice
  • That he cannot persuade her to inform her parents or to allow him to inform the parents that she is seeking contraceptive advice
  • That she is very likely to continue having sexual intercourse with or without contraceptive treatment
  • That unless she receives contraceptive advice or treatment her physical or mental health or both are likely to suffer
  • That her best interests require him to give her contraceptive advice, treatment or both without the parental consent

Regarding Gillick competency, it is not enough that she should understand the nature of the advice which is being given: she must also have a sufficient maturity to understand what is involved.

The doctor should try and find out more about the girl's partner to ensure that there is no potential abuse or harm in the relationship, e.g. large difference in age, use of drugs and alcohol.

title: Consent: children
body:
The General Medical Council have produced guidelines on obtaining consent in children:
  • at 16 years or older a young person can be treated as an adult and can be presumed to have capacity to decide
  • under the age of 16 years children may have capacity to decide, depending on their ability to understand what is involved
  • where a competent child refuses treatment, a person with parental responsibility or the court may authorise investigation or treatment which is in the child's best interests*

With regards to the provision of contraceptives to patients under 16 years of age the Fraser Guidelines state that all the following requirements should be fulfilled:
  • the young person understands the professional's advice
  • the young person cannot be persuaded to inform their parents
  • the young person is likely to begin, or to continue having, sexual intercourse with or without contraceptive treatment
  • unless the young person receives contraceptive treatment, their physical or mental health, or both, are likely to suffer
  • the young person's best interests require them to receive contraceptive advice or treatment with or without parental consent

Gillick or Fraser?

Some doctors use the term Fraser competency when referring to contraception and Gillick competency when referring to general issues of consent in children. The (widespread) rumours that Victoria Gillick removed her permission to use her name or applied copyright have recently been debunked.

More information can be found in the following article:

Wheeler R. Gillick or Fraser? A plea for consistency over competence in children BMJ 2006;332:807

*in Scotland those with parental responsibility cannot authorise procedures a competent child has refused
concept: A doctor can give contraceptive advice and treatment to a girl under the age of 16 provided that she satisfies the 'Fraser Guidelines' and is deemed 'Gillick competent'
